topic.title: ZeroTalk 'links collector' question and thoughts
topic.body:
I am new to ZeroNet and have been hanging around for some time, observing the life inside this net. After some time I've came to subjective question about data I'm browsing here. For now, I'm talking mainly about ZeroTalk and ZeroHello page that I rely on (most of the time) to watch what's new and what people are talking about, what topics are created and so on.

The question I've came into, can be formulated this way: can I reduce the amount of time spent, browsing and filtering through all this threads and info, delivered by ZeroTalk and ZeroHello results?

The thing is, I don't really want to check every topic and every comment/opinion on some topic - it's too overloading for my perception filters. So the quick thought was: can I rely on something more "informationally saturated"? Can it be the links, posted by users?

On the main page of ZeroHello there is a list of 4 tabs, currently represented as:
- ALL
- COMMENT
- MENTION
- TOPIC

Next thought was: can the 'LINKS' tab be added as a tab too? If so, how can that be possibly achieved? Will Greasemonkey, in example, be suitable and will it work out?

Within that `links` section I'd want to see the list of links, posted by any user in any topic within ZeroTalk. It could be marked with language header and, in perspective, sorted by relations such as:
- where does that link came from? Clearnet or ZeroNet?
- if it's a outside link, what source has it came from? Political mass-media or some tech source like Github/Bitbucket?

The final thought in a form of question is: can it be done without much pain, counting on current ZeroNet architecture?

The aim of such links collector, subjectively for me, would be a much more faster recognition of an info quality/quantity, throwned into the net itself. Is it more political stuff pouring out? Is it some tech waves hitting? It would give much more analysis for an eye to find out what's the mood now out there.

topic.title: Almost no ZN trackers available
topic.body:
I have two separate machines with Win and \*nix aboard. After the latest ZN release there are only 3/15 trackers available under Win and "Trackers list error" under \*nix system. What is going on? Here's the current list of ZN 0.6.5 client under Win. With newer ZN version there are no trackers under Win client too (on same Win machine, so the machine configuration is not changed).

```
zero://45.77.23.92Error (40% success)
http://open.trackerlist.xyzError (0% success)
zero://51.254.123.155Error (40% success)
udp://tracker.port443.xyzError (0% success)
https://1.tracker.eu.orgError (0% success)
zero://zero.booth.moeError (0% success)
udp://tracker.coppersurfer.tkAnnounced in 0.09 sec (83% success)
zero://boot3rdez4rzn36x.onionError (0% success)
udp://104.238.198.186Error (33% success)
zero://185.117.73.181Error (40% success)
http://tracker2.itzmx.comAnnounced in 0.43 sec (100% success)
zero://51.38.34.170Error (40% success)
zero://95.216.68.23Error (14% success)
http://open.acgnxtracker.comAnnounced in 0.15 sec (98% success)
```

topic.title: ZN Domain Name Registry: no peers found
topic.body:
So, here [/1Name2NXVi1RDPDgf5617UoW7xA6YrhM9F/](/1Name2NXVi1RDPDgf5617UoW7xA6YrhM9F/) I see pretty big list of registered domains. I tried to visit lots of them from that list, but almost all of them are not loading, giving back the "CONTENT.JSON Error Loading" or "Peers not found" message. So the question is: what is the point of that domain names being registered and why almost all of that zites(?) are unreachable? 

Also, is there any indexer (somewhat like Kaffie Search) that parsed through all of that list and stored atleast title and description of each zite from that list? If lots of zites are abandoned, or not working, or was never working but only .bit domain registered 'for future', what is the point of that list then?

topic.title: LibGen goes IPFS
topic.body:
More info here: https://www.reddit.com/r/libgen/comments/jb1hts/p2p_free_library_help_build_humanitys_free/

Please check out "Call for devs" section.

Current mirrors in clearnet:
http://libgen.rs/
https://libgen.fun/ (also accessible via the MD5 filename)|

If you are not sure what IPFS is, read here: https://freeread.org/ipfs/

1562443357_17AMQVbBa12XB3xFWKDnP2dCEx92T.body:
There is no easy answer - all these problems, like addiction, social approval and low self-esteem are a complex topics, discussed within psychological and behavioral aspects. In short, we are addicted to this little `black mirrors`  (and big ones, monitors) cause of two things: 
- the device can generate huge amount of positive reinforcements in a short term period
- social aspect even without socium itself: while interacting with a screen and some UI, this interaction performs as a powerful hormonal regulator. And, because this interaction is mainly one-sided (from user's side to his device's screen), it is intepreted by person in a most comfortable way (imaginable approval, 'look at me' stuff and etc.). So, person stays 'in mood' everytime he/she shows 'himself/herself to the world' (even if this world is virtual and imaginable, or even if photo will never reach anyone, in case with selfies).

So, it's just an act of feeding ego. Alot of people in our today's world are non-educated about their own behavior: why they are doing that, what are the aspects of doing this or that and what can be the long-term perspective of their behavior.

In more detailed answer, you will need to search some vast amount of info on human behavior topic to really catch up with some sort of a suitable answer.

Try to start with a series of Stanford lectures on human biology by Robert Sapolski: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=NNnIGh9g6fA

1563975046_1GJc2vm4vJjAKsFoFJ2D3gGmKiRac.body:
Cons:
- Cryptocurrency is still a currency. Crypto adds problems to existing concept of currency, but suggests nothing drastically new.
- You need to spend A LOT of energy to make the whole system work as intended.
- Can be used as a tool for money laundering, using mixers.
- Still buys (and sells) for real $.

And also I don't think that 'infinitely divisible' point can be considered as a 'pro'. Resources on a planet is a finite thing, our lifetime is a finite thing too. Having something with an 'infinite' possibilies is a way to wide speculation. For now it is expressed as a volatile bitcoin value, in example.

1564213187_1BqxHcQnWqCfURAwopdJnRPdqvTL9.body:
'free' is a word with a high level of abstraction. It can be interpreted in many ways. That's why it is unreliable to use it, when you're trying to be precise and concrete. We're using language - a tool, that has fistful of clutches. So, we can't 'speak freely', but only interpret to a certain level of understandability by majority of people. We can't 'think freely', cause we're limited to our own experience and tools of thinking. Watch Sapolsky lectures on human behavior and Den Dennet's lecture on 'Tools to transform our thinking'. 

And also take a look at General Semantics.

1572739729_1GJc2vm4vJjAKsFoFJ2D3gGmKiRac.body:
I mostly miss the 'spirit of newborn era'. Encouraging discoveries were in priorities. Learning through disassembling things, no mindless data scrolling. Seeing opportunities in every bit of data rather than shitloads-of-data-overload. Internet traffic was a thing with a value. Now we barely care.

It was an era of free exploration and experiments, and it also was the unique time of balance between real-life and virtual space. Those two were mixed in a somewhat 'perfect equilibrium'.

Then DMCA came in 98, and everything went downhill the road of SNAFU. Now we're approaching a full FUBAR. ^__^
Lots of people are simply escaping from reality into virtual, so there is no more balance between those two worlds: virtual place meant to be a better place, but it became yet another 'marketplace of problems', 'harbour of business' and 'dealer of noise'.

20 years back I personally saw the Internet as an instrument, that can help solve problems. Now I think we've made it look like an instrument for generating exacerbation and confusion.

1596356568_15ikhUiQxJkhNQuDUaR1RuUL45p5w.body:
> [styromaniac](#comment_2513_16NS3rBdW9zpLmLSQoD8nLTtNVsRFtVBhd): You're welcome. [...]

What do you mean by 'improving'? And what is the purpose of IFS? Is it something similar to archive.org, but in ZN? If so, how it works under the hood? Any docs would be nice (or link to repo)

I've downloaded .zip of IFS, and there is A LOT of dependencies, speaking about .js files.
In order to work with something, for me it is vital to know what parts this 'something' is constructed of.
In example, I can see the libraries like: javatarijs lib (which emulates Atari 2600 - for what?..), nes atari and dos emulators, bitcoinjs lib (for working with bitcoin wallets - where is it used?)...

Without any documentation about 'what is under the hood', there is very little chance someone will take it over and 'make it better' with little efforts... There is really a lot of react code in all.js file, and there must be some at least brief documentation on 'what is going on'. Otherwise it is very hard to drill into the structure for the 'fresh-eye' coder.

1602120041_114yCZGnUqTUcasBbAKUS6xmhQyDP.body:
Also, take a look at this zite: [citadell.bit](/1Citaftv9xvrvxG7EskEJNWXk1t9xyBL8n)
It has 3 files:
```
main.js
index.html
content.json
```

And a remote script insertion in `index.html`:
```
    <script type="text/javascript" src="//code.jquery.com/jquery-1.10.2.min.js"></script>
    <script type="text/javascript" src="http://s3.amazonaws.com/codecademy-content/courses/hour-of-code/js/alphabet.js"></script>
```
Source still loads as usual, if you have active internet connection. Again: why loading external scripts is allowed? You can, in the same way, load anything from any remote host outside ZN network. 

If it is intended behavior, then ok. But at least zite should warn the user, that some resources are loading from clearnet, no?

1603122234_1Cy3ntkN2GN9MH6EaW6eHpi4YoRS2.body:
Easiest way to do that would be to make a redirect to the topic of your project, if the project is long abandoned. Then the people will eventually figure out what to do.

What I mean:
1) You have a zite, and that zite is updated. You can fetch last updated time from `siteInfo`, looking for a `content_updated` key.
2) You have a corresponding thread on ZeroTalk or Git Center, or any other zite, where all the discussions about your project is going on. Let's say, it will be an address /XXXXX.
3) You then put a simple javascript conditional statement, something like: `if ((siteInfo['content_updated'] + 1year) > time())` then <meta> redirect to address /XXXXX instead loading the zite.

Or... we can clone ZeroMail service and add a 'delayed email sending' feature. The delayed mails sending could be triggered by anyone, who is using the mail service itself - just to send a signal to any other possible not-yet-sent emails, where script will check the current time and time in each delayed email. Since email contents are encrypted, it could be a nice way for long-term saving.

1630703227_1Cy3ntkN2GN9MH6EaW6eHpi4YoRS2.body: "everything is falling apart" - what do you mean by that? What is falling apart and why do you need to archive ZN? The whole idea of ZN is that the information is still there, if atleast 1 seed is present. It seems I quite don't understand something.

Okay, I now see the problems:
- Tor Project has deprecated v2 onions (http://127.0.0.1:43110/1fznczNZUMEMvCiqSmCZGUiv5sVnRcsTD/?Topic:1616711390_1CgdRv2BFaVqNfmK3qGVYDuA7EDmk8dJVS/Onion+v2+Deprecation+Sept+2021 - possible solution with a patch?)
- ZeroNet Namecoin domains have expired
- ZeroID is down
- Vulnerabilities that are not fixed
- Abandoned zites

Question is: how we, as a ZeroNet community, can help with this issues? What should be done in order to help resolve those? I saw geekless' fork of ZN client on Gitlab - should we join and try to dig into these problems? Those should be manageable.

1636696143_1PxcegJ1mKoMHeS73f9MvXeUWDq8B.body:
> [xanadu](#comment_45_1JTx34tPsJsZT8WWGEih4c8kxeY2kk89gH): Do they have Windows builds yet?

Nope, but you can download https://github.com/HelloZeroNet/ZeroNet-win/archive/dist-win64/ZeroNet-py3-win64.zip, unpack it. Then download https://github.com/zeronet-enhanced/ZeroNet/archive/refs/heads/massive-rework.zip and unpack it into the `core` dir of original folder, replacing files. Should work in theory :) I'm running it under Win10 without .exe file, but that require `python 3.9` installed on your machine, along with some Visual c++ compilator tools deps.

Original old version works just fine, so I think for now it is not for general usage. Lots of tests are needed before the stable release could be compiled.

I should also mention that if you move `/tools/tor` folder, it will not work - at least it is for me, showing 0 trackers (only one tracker managed to get to 25% success)

> [xanadu](#comment_61_1JTx34tPsJsZT8WWGEih4c8kxeY2kk89gH): Perfect that means it was Tor binarry making issues with ZeroNet not working :)

Yes, TOR in old bundle is not working. I will try to tinker with it.

Okay, I think it works with the latest TOR bundle, meek bridge and all the stuff (this message was sent through TOR, and my Ip is changed during the launch, as console shows).
The only bottleneck is that you have to run
`tor --service install -options ControlPort 9051` on win to run it as a service and open corresponding port.
I think it somehow needs to be embedded into init script.

> [styromaniac@kxoid.bit](#comment_230_1PxcegJ1mKoMHeS73f9MvXeUWDq8BdnSv3): You can set that in torrc.

That's not the issue. It works unstable, and I'm not quite sure where the problem is. Refer to https://github.com/zeronet-enhanced/ZeroNet/issues/5

It seems the issue with the `meek-client` - when it fails to start, TOR works.

1637248722_1JTx34tPsJsZT8WWGEih4c8kxeY2k.body:
There is always an instance admin, and if you don't like someone else's instance, you can always run up your own, so it will be uploaded there, I think? I.e. read here: https://docs.joinpeertube.org/admin-remote-storage

So your uploaded-to-an-instance video can be uploaded to Amazon S3 bucket, if instance admin set up his conf to work that way, or your video can be directly uploaded to his local HDD/SDD. If you really care about where your data is stored, you need to run an instance on your configured and controlled machine.
